eu.gricom.interpreter.basic.parser

Class JasicParser

  • java.lang.Object
    • eu.gricom.interpreter.basic.parser.JasicParser
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Parser

    public class JasicParser
extends Object
implements Parser
    This defines the Jasic parser. The parser takes in a sequence of tokens and generates an abstract syntax tree. This is the nested data structure that represents the series of statements, and the expressions (which can nest arbitrarily deeply) that they evaluate. In technical terms, what we have is a recursive descent parser, the simplest kind to hand-write. As a side-effect, this phase also stores off the line numbers for each label in the program. It's a bit gross, but it works.

    • Method Detail

      • parse

        public final List<Statement> parse()
                            throws SyntaxErrorException
        The top-level function to start parsing. This will keep consuming tokens and routing to the other parse functions for the different grammar syntax until we run out of code to parse.
        Specified by:
        parse in interface Parser
        Returns:
        The list of parsed statements.
        Throws:
        SyntaxErrorException - - marks any syntax errors

      • operator

        public final Expression operator()
                          throws SyntaxErrorException
        Parses a series of binary operator expressions into a single expression. In Basic, all operators have the same predecence and associate left-to-right. That means it will interpret: 1 + 2 * 3 - 4 / 5 like: ((((1 + 2) * 3) - 4) / 5) It works by building the expression tree one at a time. So, given this code: 1 + 2 * 3, this will: 1. Parse (1) as an atomic expression. 2. See the (+) and start a new operator expression. 3. Parse (2) as an atomic expression. 4. Build a (1 + 2) expression and replace (1) with it. 5. See the (*) and start a new operator expression. 6. Parse (3) as an atomic expression. 7. Build a ((1 + 2) * 3) expression and replace (1 + 2) with it. 8. Return the last expression built.
        Returns:
        The parsed expression.
        Throws:
        SyntaxErrorException - - marks any syntax issues

      • atomic

        public final Expression atomic()
                        throws SyntaxErrorException
        Parses an "atomic" expression. This is the highest level of precedence and contains single literal tokens like 123 and "foo", as well as parenthesized expressions.
        Returns:
        The parsed expression.
        Throws:
        SyntaxErrorException - - mark any syntax issues

      • matchNextTwoToken

        public final boolean matchNextTwoToken(TokenType eType1,
                                       TokenType eType2)
        Consumes the next two tokens if they are the given type (in order). Consumes no tokens if either check fails.
        Parameters:
        eType1 - Expected type of the next token.
        eType2 - Expected type of the subsequent token.
        Returns:
        True if tokens were consumed.

      • matchNextToken

        public final boolean matchNextToken(String strName)
        Consumes the next token if it's a word token with the given name.
        Parameters:

        Returns:
        True if the token was consumed.

      • consumeToken

        public final Token consumeToken(TokenType type)
        Consumes the next token if it's the given type. If not, throws an exception. This is for cases where the parser demands a token of a certain type in a certain position, for example a matching ) after an opening (.
        Parameters:
        type - Expected type of the next token.
        Returns:
        The consumed token.

      • consumeToken

        public final Token consumeToken(String strName)
        Consumes the next token if it's a word with the given name. If not, throws an exception.
        Parameters:
        strName - Expected name of the next word token.
        Returns:
        The consumed token.

      • lastToken

        public final Token lastToken(int iOffset)
        Gets a previously consumed token, indexing backwards. last(1) will be the token just consumed, last(2) the one before that, etc.
        Parameters:
        iOffset - How far back in the token stream to look.
        Returns:
        The consumed token.

      • getToken

        public final Token getToken(int iOffset)
        Gets an unconsumed token, indexing forward. get(0) will be the next token to be consumed, get(1) the one after that, etc.
        Parameters:
        iOffset - How far forward in the token stream to look.
        Returns:
        The yet-to-be-consumed token.

        Helper Function for JUnit.
        Parameters:
        iPosition - artificial set iPosition
